Line: Written by Peter Mehlman
Good morning.
Good morning.
How'd you sleep?
Hey, you are the couch tonight, young lady. You were all over my side.
I was not!
C'mon, I was sleeping with one cheek off the bed!
By the way, you're falling way behind on the 'I love you's.'
No, it's 15-8.
I know I can't beat ya, I'm just trying to stay competitive.
Alright c'mon, let's get some breakfast.
Uh, let me get a coat. I think I'll try a sport jacket and scarf thing, you know, like an unemployed actor. Haven't worn this one in a long time.
Ooh, cashmere?
No, gore-tex. It's new. Hey, look at this locket. What the hell is this? There's a picture in here, look at that.
Wow, this is really old. You don't know whose it is?
No, I haven't worn this jacket since I got it back from the dry-cleaner. Maybe we should ask him.
Alright, we'll stop over there.
Yeah. What do you want to get for breakfast?
Pancakes.
Oh now, c'mon, you know I'm getting pancakes.
I don't know that! Mark's Michelle is a dog.
But we can't both get pancakes, it's embarrassing. It's like one step from the couples who dress alike.
I'll get the short stack.
Ah, that's why I love ya. 15-9. Hey, how ya doin.'
We just got back from breakfast. The pancakes were dynamite.
Hey, is that my maple syrup?
You bring your own syrup?
Got to.
You got a lot to learn about pancakes.
This is my wife. She died eight years ago. I been looking all over for this!
Boy, it's a lucky thing I put the jacket on. But how did it get in the pocket?
Well, see here, the chain is broken...it must have slipped in when I was, uh...
Oh, wow.
I turned my house upside-down looking for this! It's all I have left of her.
Oh, that's so touching.
Oh, come on!
What are you talkin' about?
It's silly!
Hey, forget it!
Get outta here!
It's done!
Alright.
Well, I guess I get it too, because I'm his wife.
I didn't know you were married.
Oh...yeah...you've never met my wife, Meryl? Meryl Seinfeld.
Sure, you get the discount, too.
You might regret that, because the money my wife spends on clothes...
I'm taking him to the cleaners!
Ah - see the sense of humor? C'mere, I'm so nuts about you... I tell ya, it was fun being single, but when you meet a woman like this, you don't walk to get married - you run!
Oh, hi Greg.
Haven't seen you in a while.
Yeah. Well, today was the first day I worked out since the Central Park Mini-Marathon.
You ran the Mini-Marathon?
No, but I exercised that day.
Well, I gotta take off.
Yeah, I guess as an airline pilot, you're one of the few people who can say that and mean it. Um, do you have the time?
Eleven-thirty.
Eleven-thirty?
Wait, ten-thirty. Sorry.
Oh.
Do you have to be somewhere?
No.
Then what are you doing?
I'm just waiting for my friend George, we worked out together.
Oh. Well, it was good seeing you.
Yeah, nice to see you, too.
Uh, would you, um...can I...
Pardon?
The syrup. Would you pass the syrup?
Oh, you want to try the syrup!
Can I get you anything else?
Um, yeah...I think my wife and I'll have a little more coffee.
Okay.
And a check for my husband.
To my beautiful wife.
To my adoring husband.
Adoring? What about handsome?
I like adoring.
Sure, adoring's good for you, what does it do for me?
Excuse me...where did you get that?
Uh, we don't allow any outside syrups, jams or condiments in the restaurant. And if I catch you in here with that again...I will confiscate it.
Well, I told my wife not to bring it.
No, just Meryl.
Why, why? Why does she get it?

Because she's my wife! And I'll tell ya, I'm really enjoying this marriage thing. You think about each other. You care about each other. It's wonderful! Plus, I love saying "my wife." Once I started saying it, I couldn't stop - "my wife" this, "my wife" that...it's an amazing way to begin a sentence.
"My wife has an inner ear infection."
See?
I like that! Hey look, will you do me a favor? Will you take my quilt into the cleaners for me, so I can get the discount too?
Oh come on, we're gonna start doing this now? I can't be taking all your dry-cleaning in!
C'mon, just this one time! It's expensive!
Alright.
Hey. Hey Elaine, what do you say if neither of us is married in ten years, we get hitched?
Let's make it fifty.
We're engaged! Alright, I'm gonna get my quilt.
Alright, listen to this. Remember that guy I was telling you about at the health club?
The fly-boy.
Yeah.
Hey, where's George? I thought he was with you.
I waited, he didn't show up. Anyway, this guy gave me an open-lip kiss.
So?
So? We've always just kind've pecked. This one had a totally different dynamic.
Really.
Yeah. I mean, his upper lip landed flush on my upper lip. But his lower lip landed well below my rim.
Moisture?
Yeah. Definite moisture.
That's an open-lip kiss, alright.
Yeah. Listen, I think he's giving me a big signal...maybe he wants to change our relationship. Yeah?
Oh, uh...it's George.
Hey, what happened to you?
Nothing...little problem.
Well, what was it? I mean, I was waiting.
Can I come upstairs, please?
I mean, maybe he wants to ask me out.
I don't know why you're interested in this guy, he's a jerk.
Because, he doesn't pay any attention to me, and he ignores me.
Yeah, so?
I respect that. Mmm, what happened?
Nothing, I... said it was a little problem.
Yeah? What was it?
Well...I was in the locker room showering, and I...I had to go, so...
Here we go.
Anyway, I think the guy in the shower opposite saw me. He gave me a dirty look.
You went...in the shower?
Yeah, so what? I'm not the only one!
Do you go in the shower?
No, never.
Do you?
I take baths.
Well, what was I supposed to do? Get out of the shower, put on my bathrobe? Go all the way down to the other end? Come all the way back?
Ever hear of...holding it in?
Oh, no...no, that's very bad for the kidneys.
How do you know?
Medical journals!
Do the medical journals mention anything about standing in a pool of someone else's urine?
Hello.
Oh, hi...honey.
What are you doing here?
I just thought I'd drop off a few things.
Oh. Well, I must have been in the incinerator room when you left. Here you go, Marty.
Another quilt? Huh?
Jerry!
Uncle Leo!
Hello!
Hello.
So, if you or your wife want to drop by on Wednesday, it should be ready.
Your wife?
Yeah...my wife.
What are you talking about?
Uh...I got married.
You got married? I wasn't invited? Nobody sends me an invitation?
Well, it was sudden.
Are you ashamed of your uncle? Do I embarrass you?
No, no, it was a small ceremony.
Haven't I always been a good uncle?
Yes, yes, you have.
Who told you when you went to school that you print well?
You did, you did.
When he was younger, he had a beautiful penmanship. I used to encourage him to print.
I'm a good printer.
I remember your 'V.' It was like a perfect triangle. Whoa, there's my bus! Hello! Wait!
I'm glad you're here. This can get really boring. Do you know where I can get some good olives?
I can find out.
Would ya?
Sure.
By the way, you look really great in that leotard.
Oh, thanks.
Hey, you know what's weird? I think I had a dream about you last night.
Um, you know Greg, I...
Can I have a sip of your water?
Oh, yeah, sure.
Thanks.
I'm sorry, what were you saying?
It was nothing, forget it.
See that guy right there? I caught him urinating in the shower. I'm thinking about turning him in, too.
Honey? Could you get me something to drink?
You're right there.
C'mon, I'm sitting!
Honey, what'd you do with the can opener?
I didn't do anything with it.
Well, it's not here, it was here yesterday.
It's in the first drawer.
I'm looking in the first drawer. It's not here.
Yes, it is.
Hey...I'm not stupid. I'm looking in that drawer, there's no can opener.
Did I say you were stupid?
Well, wouldn't I have to be? You tell me there's a can opener in the drawer, I'm looking in the drawer, there's no can opener - what other conclusion could one reach?
Do you want me to go find it?
Yes. I do. You show me where there's a can opener in that drawer. Hello! I'm sorry, I'm just fighting with my wife.
Jerry, we just heard, what's going on?
Why the hell didn't you tell us?
Listen, Ma...
It was in here yesterday!
Yeah, that's what I said!
Who is she? When did this happen?
I told her you'd get married. She thought you'd never do it.
Morty, you're talking too loud.
I'm not talking loud!
You're hurting my eardrum.
Well, you must have done something with it!
I'm on the phone!
Is she there? Can we talk to her? What's her name?
Mom, I'm not married.
What?
I'm not married!
I knew it, I told ya!
Uncle Leo said.
I'm just pretending I'm married to get a discount on dry-cleaning.
A discount on dry-cleaning?
Could you make a little more noise? Listen, I'm gonna have to call you later.
Well, I give up.
Well, whoopie whoop.
Got any coffee?
Yeah. I'll get it, I'll get it! Take it easy, why are you so tired?

My quilt is still at the cleaners. Jerry, I can't sleep without my quilt. Like the other night? I was cold. So, last night, I turn up the heat - it's too hot. I open up a window - it's too cold. I can't get into a zone!
What is that?
Oh, I forgot.
Hey, I'm sorry about all that can opener stuff.
Yeah, me too. Love you.
Love you.
Well, goodnight.
Goodnight.
They could kick me out of the health club if he tells them!
So what do you want me to do?
Talk to him!
How can I do that?
You said the guy gave you an open-lipped kiss!
Yes, but then he wiped his hand on the top of the bottle when I offered him water!
Well, that doesn't mean anything!
Are you kidding? That's very significant! If he was interested in me, he'd want my germs! He'd just crave my germs!
She's right, George. Bottle-wipe is big.
Well, what about the open-lipped kiss?
Bottle-wipe supercedes it.
Yeah, you're right, you're right. Alright, maybe he's not interested, but you still know him - can't you just ask him?
George...but if I ask him now, I will have no chance of going out with him.
Why?
Aha. Aha. Could it be because you don't want him to know that you have a friend who pees in the shower, is that it?!
No, that's not it!
Oh, I think it is! I think that's exactly what it is!
Why couldn't you just wait?
I was there! I saw a drain!
Since when is a drain a toilet?!
It's all pipes! What's the difference?!
Different pipes go to different places! You're gonna mix 'em up!
I'll call a plumber right now!
Alright, can we just drop all the pee-pipe stuff here?
Okay! Okay! I will talk to him.
Jerry, I think that quilt is ready.
Alright.
Well, you gotta pick it up for me!
Alright, I'll pick it up, but it's the last time I'm doin' it!
I'm so tired!
Boy, you don't look good.
Huh? I don't?
No, you look pale.
Pale? Oh my God...I gotta meet Anna's parents today!
Hello? Oh, hi honey. Yes, I told him. I'll get it. Whenever. Okay, I'm sorry...
I'm sorry, it's not ready yet.
Not ready? It has to be ready! What kind of a business are you running here?
Who the hell are you? It's not your quilt.
He's a very good friend of mine, he's kind've like an older brother to me...when things don't go right, he kinda takes it personally.
Well, uh...maybe tomorrow.
Maybe.
Oh, it's okay, it'll be okay.
Alright, I'm gonna see you later.
Where you goin'?
I gotta meet Anna's parents today, remember? I look terrible! I'm gonna hit the tanning machines.
I can't believe you still do that. You know those things are bad for ya.
Hey, that's how I maintain my glow.
I'm goin' home.
Excuse me? Uh, how much would it cost to clean this?
Oh, about thirteen dollars.
Thirteen? Well, I can't afford that.
Well, I'm sorry.
Hi, Greg.
Hey, Elaine. I'll be off in a second.
I got the machine next, buddy.
It's all yours.
What happened? Did he bring it up?
Never mind that, look at the signal I just got.
Signal? What signal?
Lookit. He knew I was gonna use the machine next, he didn't wipe his sweat off. That's a gesture of intimacy.
I'll tell you what that is - that's a violation of club rules. Now I got him! And you're my witness!
Listen, George! Listen! He knew what he was doing, this was a signal.
A guy leaves a puddle of sweat, that's a signal?
Yeah! It's a social thing.
What if he left you a used Kleenex, what's that, a valentine? Now you go up to him and you tell him that if he's thinking of turning me in, that I got the goods on him!
No! I won't be a party to this.
So you're gonna let me get suspended for shower urination?
Okay, I'll talk to him. But you're putting me in a very difficult position.
I won't let you do this!
I want to!
But it isn't right! I can't.
Give me the clothes.
Jerry, please. What about her?
Oh, the hell with her.
No, Jerry, please!
I'm not gonna let you walk out of my life.
I can't fight you.
Do you want box or hanger?
You decide.
You're really working up quite a sweat today, huh?
Yeah. Oh, there's the manager. Good. I think I'm gonna talk to her about that guy, you know, we cannot have people like that in here.
Are you sure you want to do that?
Yeah. He's disgusting! Besides, I'll take any chance I can to talk to her.
You're interested in...in her?
Very.
Ah. You know, uh...I'm engaged. Yep, gettin' married in fifty years.
Oh good, there he is. I wanna be able to point him out.
You know, Greg, I wouldn't do that if I were you.
Why?
Well, correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't it a violation of club policy to not wipe down a machine after using it?
Oh, I see...you're friends with the urinator, aren't you?
Yeah, well, at least he had a drain.
Here you go. Excuse me, this isn't mine.
Oh, yes it is. Your husband brought it in himself.
Really? Thank you.
That's him!
You son of a bitch!
I'm sorry.
Who is she? I want to know who she is.
It doesn't matter. I want a divorce.
A divorce? Oh, so you can marry her and give her the discount?
Yes, that's right.
What happened to us, Jerry?
I'll tell you what happened. We got married.
I'm sorry, this is my fault. I pushed it on you.
No. I guess I just wasn't ready for the responsibilities of a pretend marriage.
Goodbye, Jerry. Oh, I forgot......this is your maple syrup.
It's alright, I want you to have it.
Okay, thanks.
We'll always have...pancakes.
Bye, Jerry.
I thought you said you was bringin' a white boy home! I don't see a white boy! I see a damn fool!
